values.value: Lack of domain-specific linguistically-oriented corpora for semantic frame information and semantic role labeling in biomedical information extraction, particularly for gene regulation and expression events

Motivation.text: Existing event corpora within the domain (e.g., [21] and [23]) are not specifically geared to support the acquisition of semantic frame information for verbs. The bio-NLP community has, until now, lacked a domain-specific linguistically-oriented corpus in which detailed semantic information for a wide range of both verbs and nominalised verbs has been annotated. This has limited the amount of research undertaken on the production of domain-specific semantic frame resources and SRLs.
Motivation.relevance: Directly states the core research problem addressed by the GREC corpus: absence of domain-specific annotated resources for semantic frame extraction in biomedical texts, particularly for gene regulation/expression events

Background.text: Due to domain-specific features of texts and the types of events to be recognised, IE systems must be adapted to deal with specific domains. A well-established method of carrying out this adaptation is through training using annotated corpora (e.g., [1012]). [...] our annotation aims to identify, as exhaustively as possible, all structurally-related arguments within the same sentence. [...] To our knowledge, the GREC provides the richest annotation to date within the biomedical field, in terms of the number of arguments types and their characterisation. As such, the corpus is specifically designed to contribute to the development of bio-specific semantic frame resources and semantic role labellers (SRLs) which, although active areas of research within the general language domain, have received less attention within the bio-IE domain.
Background.relevance: Contextualizes the problem: existing IE systems lack domain-specific annotated corpora for biomedical semantic role labeling, particularly for complex events like gene regulation

Related work.text: Whilst events are often identified by verbs, nominalised verbs play a particularly important role within biomedical texts, and often outnumber other domain-specific verbal forms [25]. However, it is acknowledged that they are more difficult to process than verbs [26] and are currently only dealt with by a small number of systems, often in a limited way (e.g., [17, 27, 28]). [...] Some studies (e.g., [34, 35]) have shown that, to a certain extent, general language resources can also be useful in the training of SRLs for biomedical texts, due to the fact that many verbs appear in texts from both the general language and biomedical domains, and often behave in similar ways. However, the cited works concede that, whilst such SRLs may produce adequate results for certain predicates, training using biomedical corpora is also needed.
Related work.relevance: Highlights the specific gap: nominalized verbs (critical in biomedicine) are under-represented in existing resources, and general-language SRLs are insufficient for domain-specific needs

values.value: Insufficient coverage of sublanguage grammar features in biomedical NLP, including domain-specific syntactic/semantic properties of verbs and nominalizations (e.g., 'methylate', 'translation' as protein synthesis)

Related work.text: NLP systems must take such grammars into account to allow accurate processing of text within specialist domains [37]. Sublanguage grammar features that are relevant to our work include the following: The types of events found in biological sciences are often described using verbs/nominalised verbs that do not feature prominently in general language [26], e.g., methylate. Verbs/nominalised verbs that occur in both the general and specialised language domains may have different syntactic and semantic properties in each domain, e.g., differing numbers of arguments [38], as well as different meanings. For example, translation generally means rendering one language into other, while in Molecular Biology it specifies the process of protein synthesis from an mRNA template.
Related work.relevance: Explicitly identifies the sublanguage grammar gap: domain-specific verbs/nominalizations (e.g., 'methylate', 'translation') have unique syntactic/semantic properties not captured by general-language resources

values.value: Limited interoperability and comparative evaluation of biomedical corpora due to diverse annotation formats and lack of standardized resources for semantic role labeling

Conclusion.text: Firstly, in response to the current diversity of corpus annotation formats and the problems this causes in their comparative evaluation [63], a shared format has been created for resources for biomedical relation extraction [15], together with a standard for the evaluation of relation extraction methods using this data [64]. We plan to convert our own corpus to this format, which has already been carried out for several biomedical corpora, e.g., [13, 16, 21, 23].
Conclusion.relevance: Directly addresses the interoperability problem: diverse annotation formats hinder comparative evaluation and reuse of biomedical corpora

values.value: Poor performance of biomedical IE systems due to lack of richly annotated training data combining linguistic (semantic roles) and biological (concept types) features

Background.text: Semantic searching above the level of concepts depends on prior processing to recognise relations or events in texts, which is carried out by information extraction (IE) systems. [...] Our approach is based on the fact that many events are focussed on either verbs (e.g., transcribe, regulate) or nominalised verbs (e.g., transcription, regulation). Both types of word behave in similar ways, in that they specify arguments that can convey a range of different types of information related to the event. For each relevant event, our annotation aims to identify, as exhaustively as possible, all structurally-related arguments within the same sentence. Each argument is assigned a semantic role from a fixed set of 13 roles. Where appropriate, arguments are also assigned a biological concept type.
Background.relevance: Links IE system performance to the need for combined linguistic (semantic roles) and biological (concept types) annotations

Results.text: Initial machine learning experiments using the GREC [45] suggest that it can be used to train IE components with reasonably good performance, with both named entity extraction and semantic role labelling having achieved F-scores of around 60%, based on 10-fold cross validation.
Results.relevance: Empirical evidence that existing systems suffer from ~60% F-scores, implying room for improvement with richer annotations

values.value: 240 MEDLINE abstracts

Results.text: Using the scheme, we have created the Gene Regulation Event Corpus (GREC), consisting of 240 MEDLINE abstracts, in which events relating to gene regulation and expression have been annotated by biologists.
Results.relevance: Direct mention of the primary material used for constructing the GREC corpus.

Conclusion.text: We have designed an event annotation scheme for biomedical texts and produced an associated corpus, the GREC, consisting of 240 MEDLINE abstracts annotated with 3067 gene regulation event instances.
Conclusion.relevance: Explicit confirmation of the material (240 MEDLINE abstracts) forming the GREC corpus.

Methods.text: Candidate abstracts for annotation for the final GREC were selected from species-specific corpora of MEDLINE abstracts collected by EMBL-EBI, who chose abstracts relevant to the E. coli and human species using their own rule-based species-filtering methods.
Methods.relevance: Describes the source and selection process of the MEDLINE abstracts used as material.

values.value: Gene Regulation Event Corpus (GREC)

Background.text: Our work has been concerned with the development of such a corpus for the biomedical field, the Gene Regulation Event Corpus (GREC), consisting of MEDLINE abstracts semantically annotated with event information.
Background.relevance: Introduces the GREC as the primary material/corpus developed in the study.

Results.text: Using the scheme, we have created the Gene Regulation Event Corpus (GREC), consisting of 240 MEDLINE abstracts, in which events relating to gene regulation and expression have been annotated by biologists.
Results.relevance: Explicitly names the GREC as the output material of the annotation effort.

Conclusion.text: The corpus can act as a basis for creating domain-specific semantic frame resources, and has already been used in the production of semantic frames for inclusion within the BioLexicon [44].
Conclusion.relevance: Reinforces the GREC as a foundational material for further research.

values.value: E. coli and human MEDLINE abstracts

Methods.text: Candidate abstracts for annotation for the final GREC were selected from species-specific corpora of MEDLINE abstracts collected by EMBL-EBI, who chose abstracts relevant to the E. coli and human species using their own rule-based species-filtering methods.
Methods.relevance: Specifies the species-specific focus of the MEDLINE abstracts used as material.

Results.text: Table 5 shows the top 10 most common words (verbs and nominalised verbs) which express events, both in the corpus as a whole, and separately for the E. coli and human parts of the corpus.
Results.relevance: Confirms the division of the corpus material into E. coli and human subsets.

values.value: BioLexicon

Conclusion.text: The corpus has already been used in the development of the BioLexicon [44]. This unique text mining resource for biology provides and links syntactic and semantic frame information for a large number of biomedical sublanguage verbs.
Conclusion.relevance: Identifies BioLexicon as a secondary material/resource derived from or linked to the GREC.

Motivation.text: The GREC consists of 240 MEDLINE abstracts, which have been annotated with a total of 3067 events. Whilst of modest size compared to some other domain-specific event-annotated corpora (e.g., [21]), this is balanced by the richness of the annotations. The corpus has already been used in the development of the BioLexicon [44].
Motivation.relevance: Explicitly connects the GREC material to the BioLexicon resource.

values.value: WordFreak

Methods.text: The annotation of the GREC was performed using a Java-based annotation tool called WordFreak (http://wordfreak.sourceforge.net/[59]).
Methods.relevance: Identifies WordFreak as the software tool used to annotate the GREC material.

values.value: GENIA tagger

Methods.text: Prior to annotation, chunks are automatically identified by the GENIA tagger [55].
Methods.relevance: Explicitly names the GENIA tagger as a tool used in preprocessing the GREC material.

Annotation scheme.text: The basis of this list was a set of 229 hand-picked gene regulation verbs provided by the European Bioinformatics Institute (EMBL-EBI). We augmented this list through the automatic extraction of further verbs from an E. coli corpus. This corpus contains approximately 33,000 MEDLINE abstracts and was also provided by EMBL-EBI. The automatic extraction was carried out by identifying those verbs whose syntactic arguments corresponded either to terms identified by the TerMine tool (http://www.nactem.ac.uk/software/termine/) or biological named entities identified by the GENIA tagger [55].
Annotation scheme.relevance: Confirms the use of the GENIA tagger for named entity recognition in the material.

values.value: TerMine tool

Annotation scheme.text: The automatic extraction was carried out by identifying those verbs whose syntactic arguments corresponded either to terms identified by the TerMine tool (http://www.nactem.ac.uk/software/termine/) or biological named entities identified by the GENIA tagger [55].
Annotation scheme.relevance: Explicitly names the TerMine tool as part of the preprocessing pipeline for the GREC material.

values.value: Gene Regulation Ontology (GRO)

Background.text: Where appropriate, arguments are also assigned a biological concept type linked to the Gene Regulation Ontology.
Background.relevance: Introduces the Gene Regulation Ontology (GRO) as a linked resource for biological concept types in the GREC.

Conclusion.text: From the biological perspective, appropriate arguments are additionally assigned a biological concept type from a hierarchically-structured set that is tailored to the gene regulation domain. The concepts are mapped to classes in the Gene Regulation Ontology (GRO) [43].
Conclusion.relevance: Explicitly connects the GREC material to the Gene Regulation Ontology (GRO).

values.value: UMLS SPECIALIST lexicon

Related work.text: The UMLS SPECIALIST lexicon [41], which includes many biomedical terms, is larger scale, but includes only syntactic, and not semantic, information about verbs.
Related work.relevance: References the UMLS SPECIALIST lexicon as a related resource in the domain, though not directly used in GREC.

values.value: 353 gene regulation verbs

Annotation scheme.text: The basis of this list was a set of 229 hand-picked gene regulation verbs provided by the European Bioinformatics Institute (EMBL-EBI). We augmented this list through the automatic extraction of further verbs from an E. coli corpus. This corpus contains approximately 33,000 MEDLINE abstracts and was also provided by EMBL-EBI. The complete list was subsequently reviewed for relevance by a biology expert, resulting in a list of 353 verbs.
Annotation scheme.relevance: Describes the creation of a list of 353 gene regulation verbs as a supplementary material/resource.

values.value: 33,000 MEDLINE abstracts (E. coli corpus)

Annotation scheme.text: We augmented this list through the automatic extraction of further verbs from an E. coli corpus. This corpus contains approximately 33,000 MEDLINE abstracts and was also provided by EMBL-EBI.
Annotation scheme.relevance: Identifies a secondary corpus of 33,000 MEDLINE abstracts used for verb extraction.

values.value: Annotation scheme centered on verbs and nominalized verbs for gene regulation events, assigning 13 semantic roles and biological concept types linked to the Gene Regulation Ontology (GRO).

Background.text: Our approach is based on the fact that many events are focussed on either verbs (e.g., transcribe, regulate) or nominalised verbs (e.g., transcription, regulation). Both types of word behave in similar ways, in that they specify arguments that can convey a range of different types of information related to the event. For each relevant event, our annotation aims to identify, as exhaustively as possible, all structurally-related arguments within the same sentence. Each argument is assigned a semantic role from a fixed set of 13 roles. Where appropriate, arguments are also assigned a biological concept type. The GREC may be downloaded from http://www.nactem.ac.uk/GREC/.
Background.relevance: Describes the core methodology of semantic role labeling (SRL) and biological concept assignment for gene regulation events, explicitly mentioning the use of verbs/nominalized verbs and the 13-role scheme.

Results.text: We have defined a new scheme for annotating sentence-bound gene regulation events, centred on both verbs and nominalised verbs. For each event instance, all participants (arguments) in the same sentence are identified and assigned a semantic role from a rich set of 13 roles tailored to biomedical research articles, together with a biological concept type linked to the Gene Regulation Ontology.
Results.relevance: Directly states the methodological focus on verbs/nominalized verbs, 13 semantic roles, and GRO-linked biological concepts.

values.value: Iterative annotator training with quantitative inter-annotator agreement (IAA) scoring using F-measure, including 5 fortnightly cycles with feedback and group discussions to refine guidelines.

Methods.text: Initial training sessions introduced the annotation tool and the task, with a particular emphasis being placed on clear positive and negative examples of gene regulation and expression events. This was considered particularly important for those annotators with less experience in gene regulation and expression. The initial training sessions were followed up by 5 fortnightly cycles, during which abstracts were firstly annotated by the annotators and then examined by 2 of the authors (one with biological expertise and the other with linguistic expertise), who produced individual feedback reports for each annotator prior to the start of the next cycle of annotation. Additional regular group sessions allowed problems to be discussed in more detail. The calculation of IAA scores after each training cycle provided a quantitative measure of improvement during the training period.
Methods.relevance: Details the structured training methodology, including iterative cycles, feedback, and IAA scoring to ensure annotation consistency.

Calculating inter-annotator agreement.text: We have defined a novel evaluation methodology which calculates IAA for a number of separate subtasks of the annotation process. [...] Whilst the Kappa statistic has become a standard way of calculating IAA for classification tasks, it is problematic for most of the annotation subtasks outlined above, as it requires classifications to correspond to mutually exclusive and discrete categories. [...] We have thus chosen to follow [61] in choosing the F-Score to calculate IAA, as it can be applied straightforwardly to all of the above annotation subtasks.
Calculating inter-annotator agreement.relevance: Explains the use of F-measure (instead of Kappa) for quantifying IAA across multiple annotation subtasks, which is a key part of the training method.

values.value: Automated chunk-based span annotation using GENIA tagger to ensure consistent argument text spans, excluding descriptive prepositional phrases (e.g., 'of 23 kDa').

Consistent annotation of text spans.text: In order to promote consistent choice of spans, we have created a number of guidelines which are mostly based on syntactic chunks. Prior to annotation, chunks are automatically identified by the GENIA tagger. [...] According to our guidelines, annotated text spans should normally consist of (sequences of) complete chunks, thus alleviating many issues relating to the exact words that should be included within an argument text span. [...] A further guideline stipulates that argument text spans must consist only of base NP chunks, and that additional descriptive information, usually introduced by prepositions, must be excluded from argument text spans.
Consistent annotation of text spans.relevance: Describes the method for ensuring consistent argument span annotation via GENIA tagger chunks and explicit exclusion of descriptive prepositional phrases.

values.value: Customized WordFreak annotation tool with automated verb highlighting, chunk color-coding, and role-specific chunk restrictions (e.g., ADVP chunks limited to MANNER role).

Software.text: The annotation of the GREC was performed using a Java-based annotation tool called WordFreak. [...] The customisation helps annotators to conform to the guidelines in a number of ways. For example, occurrences of biologically-relevant verbs are automatically highlighted. In addition, colour-coding is used to distinguish different types of chunks, whilst certain restrictions are imposed in the tool as regards the types of chunks that can constitute different types of semantic arguments, e.g., ADVP chunks can only be labelled with the MANNER role.
Software.relevance: Describes the tool customization (WordFreak) to enforce guidelines via verb highlighting, chunk color-coding, and role-chunk restrictions.

values.value: Corpus selection via EMBL-EBI species-filtered MEDLINE abstracts (E. coli and human), further screened for gene regulation relevance by a biology expert.

Corpus characteristics and statistics.text: Candidate abstracts for annotation for the final GREC were selected from species-specific corpora of MEDLINE abstracts collected by EMBL-EBI, who chose abstracts relevant to the E. coli and human species using their own rule-based species-filtering methods. The candidate abstracts were further screened for relevance to gene regulation by one of the authors with biological expertise.
Corpus characteristics and statistics.relevance: Explains the two-step corpus selection method: EMBL-EBI species filtering followed by expert screening for gene regulation relevance.

values.value: Multi-faceted inter-annotator agreement (IAA) evaluation using F-score for 5 subtasks: event identification, argument identification (relaxed/exact spans), semantic role assignment, biological concept identification, and category assignment (exact/parent/supercategory).

Calculating inter-annotator agreement.text: We have defined a novel evaluation methodology which calculates IAA for a number of separate subtasks of the annotation process. These subtasks are as follows: Event identification (how frequently annotators agree on which events to annotate); Argument identification (for agreed events, how frequently the same arguments are chosen by each annotator). For this task, we calculate separate agreement rates corresponding to: a. Relaxed span matches, where argument text spans identified by a pair of annotators at least overlap with each other, but do not necessarily match exactly. b. Exact span matches, where argument text spans identified by a pair of annotators match exactly.; Semantic role assignment (for agreed arguments, how often the same semantic roles are assigned by each annotator); Biological concept identification (within agreed arguments, how often annotators identify the same biological concepts); Biological concept category assignment (for agreed biological concepts, how often the assigned categories are agreed upon by each annotator). For this task, we calculate 3 different agreement rates, i.e., a. Exact category matches, where each annotator has assigned exactly the same concept label. b. Matches including parent, where we also consider as matches those cases where the category assigned by one annotator is the parent concept of the category assigned by the other annotator. c. Supercategory assignment, where we consider only whether each annotator has assigned a concept within the same top level superclass, i.e., Nucleic_Acids, Proteins, Living_Systems, Processes and Experimental.
Calculating inter-annotator agreement.relevance: Comprehensively lists all 6 IAA subtasks and their evaluation criteria, including relaxed/exact spans and hierarchical concept matching (parent/supercategory).

values.value: Hierarchical biological concept assignment using the Gene Regulation Ontology (GRO), with annotators instructed to assign the most specific concept possible (66.91% achieved).

Biological concepts.text: Annotators were instructed to assign the most specific concept possible in the hierarchy; the results show that 66.91% of assignments indeed constitute the most specific concepts.
Biological concepts.relevance: Describes the method of hierarchical concept assignment tied to GRO, with a quantitative result (66.91%) for specificity compliance.

values.value: Post-training quality control via double-annotation of 25% of abstracts by all annotators, with manual discrepancy analysis to refine guidelines.

Quality control.text: To ensure annotation quality was maintained in the final GREC, approximately one quarter of the abstracts was annotated by all annotators. [...] Finally, we examine some types of annotator discrepancies that were found through manual examination of the corpus.
Quality control.relevance: Describes the quality control method: double-annotation of 25% of abstracts and manual discrepancy analysis.

values.value: Domain-specific semantic role set (13 roles) derived from VerbNet/PropBank but tailored for biomedicine, including CONDITION and DESCRIPTIVE-THEME/AGENT roles for gene regulation events.

Semantic roles.text: Starting with the generic semantic roles proposed for VerbNet [29] and PropBank [30], we examined a large number of relevant events within MEDLINE abstracts, in consultation with biologists. We concluded that arguments of gene regulation and expression events may be characterised using a subset of these general language roles, with the addition of the domain-specific CONDITION role. [...] The full set of roles is shown in Table 2. In general, definitions of argument types normally specified as adjuncts, such as MANNER, INSTRUMENT, CONDITION and LOCATION, can be problematic to distinguish from each other. However, our use of more biologically-oriented definitions for these cases aims to reduce discrepancies.
Semantic roles.relevance: Explains the adaptation of VerbNet/PropBank roles for biomedicine, including the addition of CONDITION and DESCRIPTIVE-THEME/AGENT, with biological definitions to reduce ambiguity.

values.value: Verb/nominalized verb list compilation via EMBL-EBI hand-picked verbs (229) augmented by automatic extraction from an E. coli corpus (33k abstracts) using TerMine and GENIA tagger, reviewed by a biology expert (final list: 353 verbs).

Gene regulation and expression events.text: Annotators were helped by (but not restricted to) a list of verbs which we created that potentially denote gene regulation and expression events. These are automatically highlighted by the annotation software, WordFreak, in each abstract to be annotated. The basis of this list was a set of 229 hand-picked gene regulation verbs provided by the European Bioinformatics Institute (EMBL-EBI). We augmented this list through the automatic extraction of further verbs from an E. coli corpus. This corpus contains approximately 33,000 MEDLINE abstracts and was also provided by EMBL-EBI. The automatic extraction was carried out by identifying those verbs whose syntactic arguments corresponded either to terms identified by the TerMine tool or biological named entities identified by the GENIA tagger. The complete list was subsequently reviewed for relevance by a biology expert, resulting in a list of 353 verbs.
Gene regulation and expression events.relevance: Details the method for compiling the verb list: EMBL-EBI hand-picked verbs (229) + automatic extraction from 33k E. coli abstracts using TerMine/GENIA, reviewed by an expert (final: 353 verbs).

values.value: The Gene Regulation Event Corpus (GREC) was created, consisting of 240 MEDLINE abstracts annotated with 3067 gene regulation event instances, featuring a rich set of 13 semantic roles tailored to biomedical research and linked to the Gene Regulation Ontology (GRO).

Results.text: We have defined a new scheme for annotating sentence-bound gene regulation events, centred on both verbs and nominalised verbs. For each event instance, all participants (arguments) in the same sentence are identified and assigned a semantic role from a rich set of 13 roles tailored to biomedical research articles, together with a biological concept type linked to the Gene Regulation Ontology. To our knowledge, our scheme is unique within the biomedical field in terms of the range of event arguments identified. Using the scheme, we have created the Gene Regulation Event Corpus (GREC), consisting of 240 MEDLINE abstracts, in which events relating to gene regulation and expression have been annotated by biologists. A novel method of evaluating various different facets of the annotation task showed that average inter-annotator agreement rates fall within the range of 66% - 90%.
Results.relevance: Directly describes the creation of GREC, its size (240 abstracts, 3067 events), and its unique features (13 semantic roles, linkage to GRO).

values.value: Average inter-annotator agreement rates for GREC annotation tasks ranged from 66% to 90% F-score, with semantic role assignment and argument identification achieving 88% or higher agreement.

Results.text: A novel method of evaluating various different facets of the annotation task showed that average inter-annotator agreement rates fall within the range of 66% - 90%.
Results.relevance: Provides quantitative validation of GREC's annotation quality via inter-annotator agreement metrics.

Conclusion.text: Average agreement rates for the various tasks fell within the range of 66% - 90% F-score. Through error analysis of the corpus, we identified the most problematic issues, which included difficulties in assigning particular semantic roles, particularly CONDITION and DESCRIPTIVE-THEME. [...] Particularly high levels of agreement (88% or above) are achieved for both the identification of semantic arguments and the assignment of semantic roles to these arguments.
Conclusion.relevance: Reinforces the F-score range and highlights specific high-agreement tasks (semantic roles, argument identification).

values.value: GREC combines linguistically-oriented features (event-independent semantic roles tuned to biomedicine) and biologically-oriented features (biological concepts linked to the Gene Regulation Ontology), enabling flexible queries like 'LOCATION:E. coli, AGENT:NifA activates which THEME:GENE'.

Conclusion.text: The corpus is unique within the biomedical field in that it combines both linguistically-oriented features (i.e., event-independent semantic roles tuned to the domain) and biologically-oriented features (i.e., biological concepts linked to the Gene Regulation Ontology [43]). [...] The combination of semantic role and biological concept labels provides a rich annotation, aimed at allowing users to have a large amount of flexibility over the type of query they specify and to have control over the specificity or generality of certain parts of the query, e.g.: In LOCATION:E. coli, AGENT:NifA activates which THEME:GENE.
Conclusion.relevance: Explains GREC's dual linguistic/biological design and its practical utility for flexible queries.

values.value: Initial machine learning experiments using GREC achieved F-scores of ~60% for both named entity extraction and semantic role labelling (10-fold cross-validation), demonstrating its utility for training biomedical IE systems.

Motivation.text: Initial machine learning experiments using the GREC [45] suggest that it can be used to train IE components with reasonably good performance, with both named entity extraction and semantic role labelling having achieved F-scores of around 60%, based on 10-fold cross validation.
Motivation.relevance: Provides empirical validation of GREC's applicability to machine learning tasks in biomedical IE.

values.value: GREC's semantic role set (13 roles) was found sufficient to characterize 3067 events, with the 'Underspecified' role used only 11 times, indicating comprehensive coverage of gene regulation/expression arguments.

Results and discussion.text: In addition to the 13 roles already introduced, there is a further role named Underspecified, which was to be assigned by annotators to arguments that could not be characterised by one of the 13 defined roles. However, the fact that the Underspecified role was only assigned 11 times in the whole corpus suggests that our originally-defined role set is sufficient to characterise the vast majority of semantic arguments.
Results and discussion.relevance: Validates the adequacy of the 13-role scheme for annotating 3067 events, with minimal use of the 'Underspecified' fallback.

values.value: GREC's biological concept assignments achieved high agreement for coarse-grained categories but faced challenges with fine-grained classification, particularly for 'Gene' (dominant but rarely subtyped) and 'Transcription_Factor' (more frequent in human than E. coli abstracts).

Conclusion.text: As regards biological concepts, our results show that, although high levels of agreement can be achieved when considering a coarse-grained set of categories, the use of a fine-grained classification caused some difficulties. [...] Gene constitutes the most commonly assigned concept in both parts of the corpus. It is a general, rather than a specific concept in the Nucleic_Acids hierarchy. However, the frequency of assignments of its specific subtypes, i.e., Mutant_Gene, ORF and Allele is very low, with 19, 10 and 1 assignments, respectively. [...] The category Transcription_Factor also has far more assignments than its sub-categories, Repressor and Activator in the human part of the corpus. However, Transcription_Factor is not nearly as frequent in E. coli abstracts as in human corpus.
Conclusion.relevance: Highlights the coarse vs. fine-grained agreement disparity and species-specific concept distribution (e.g., Transcription_Factor in human vs. E. coli).

values.value: Future work includes converting GREC to a shared biomedical relation extraction format and integrating it into the U-Compare system to enhance interoperability and accessibility for text mining tasks.

Conclusion.text: Firstly, in response to the current diversity of corpus annotation formats and the problems this causes in their comparative evaluation [63], a shared format has been created for resources for biomedical relation extraction [15], together with a standard for the evaluation of relation extraction methods using this data [64]. We plan to convert our own corpus to this format, which has already been carried out for several biomedical corpora, e.g., [13, 16, 21, 23]. Secondly, we plan to develop a corpus reader which will allow the GREC to be made available within the U-Compare system [65](http://u-compare.org).
Conclusion.relevance: Outlines concrete plans for GREC's format conversion and integration into U-Compare for broader usability.

values.value: Error analysis revealed that the most problematic semantic roles for annotators were CONDITION (often confused with MANNER/TEMPORAL) and DESCRIPTIVE-THEME (confused with THEME), suggesting a need for refined role definitions or additional training.

Quality control.text: Amongst the most important semantic roles, both in terms of frequency of occurrence and according to [20], CONDITION is the one with the lowest rates of agreement. [...] The most common confusions are with the MANNER and TEMPORAL roles. [...] Regarding the DESCRIPTIVE-THEME role, the most common type of confusion is with THEME. [...] In general, DESCRIPTIVE-THEME and DESCRIPTIVE-AGENT have less strict definitions than other roles, in that the only restriction imposed is that they should be assigned to arguments that describe characteristics or behaviour of the AGENT or THEME. This, together with the fact that they are not particularly commonly occurring, could have made them more difficult to assign accurately.
Quality control.relevance: Identifies specific roles (CONDITION, DESCRIPTIVE-THEME) as sources of annotator confusion and proposes solutions (refined definitions, training).

values.value: GREC's annotation scheme was applied to 240 MEDLINE abstracts (120 E. coli, 120 human) by 6 biology PhD annotators over 876 person-hours, with training emphasizing syntactic chunk-based span consistency and domain-specific semantic role definitions.

Methods.text: Candidate abstracts for annotation for the final GREC were selected from species-specific corpora of MEDLINE abstracts collected by EMBL-EBI, who chose abstracts relevant to the E. coli and human species using their own rule-based species-filtering methods. The candidate abstracts were further screened for relevance to gene regulation by one of the authors with biological expertise. [...] The effort expended by the 6 annotators amounted to a total of 876 person hours (equivalent to 6.4 person months).
Methods.relevance: Details the corpus composition (240 abstracts, split by species), annotator profile (6 biology PhDs), and effort (876 hours).

Annotation scheme.text: To accompany the annotation scheme, we have produced a detailed set of annotation guidelines, as these are necessary to aid in the achievement of high quality annotations [5254]. The structure and content of these guidelines were iteratively refined in discussion with domain experts and with annotators (via group discussion sessions following annotation training phrases and full annotation cycles).
Annotation scheme.relevance: Highlights the iterative guideline refinement and emphasis on syntactic chunks/span consistency.

values.value: GREC's top 10 event-triggering verbs/nominalizations (e.g., 'regulate/regulation', 'bind/binding', 'express/expression') account for 4550% of all annotated events, with nominalized verbs (e.g., 'expression') dominating in E. coli abstracts.

Results and discussion.text: Table 5 shows the top 10 most common words (verbs and nominalised verbs) which express events, both in the corpus as a whole, and separately for the E. coli and human parts of the corpus. In each case, events centred on these 10 words constitute 45 - 50% of the total events annotated, suggesting that the majority of relevant events are centred on a relatively small set of words. [...] In the E. coli portion of the corpus, for example, twice as many events are centred on the nominalised verb expression than any other word.
Results and discussion.relevance: Quantifies the dominance of top 10 verbs/nominalizations (4550% of events) and highlights species-specific patterns (e.g., 'expression' in E. coli).

values.value: Lack of domain-specific linguistically-oriented corpora for semantic frame information and semantic role labeling in biomedical information extraction, particularly for gene regulation and expression events

Motivation.text: Existing event corpora within the domain (e.g., [21] and [23]) are not specifically geared to support the acquisition of semantic frame information for verbs. The bio-NLP community has, until now, lacked a domain-specific linguistically-oriented corpus in which detailed semantic information for a wide range of both verbs and nominalised verbs has been annotated. This has limited the amount of research undertaken on the production of domain-specific semantic frame resources and SRLs.
Motivation.relevance: Directly states the core research problem addressed by the GREC corpus: absence of domain-specific annotated resources for semantic frame extraction in biomedical texts, particularly for gene regulation/expression events

Background.text: Due to domain-specific features of texts and the types of events to be recognised, IE systems must be adapted to deal with specific domains. A well-established method of carrying out this adaptation is through training using annotated corpora (e.g., [1012]). [...] our annotation aims to identify, as exhaustively as possible, all structurally-related arguments within the same sentence. [...] To our knowledge, the GREC provides the richest annotation to date within the biomedical field, in terms of the number of arguments types and their characterisation. As such, the corpus is specifically designed to contribute to the development of bio-specific semantic frame resources and semantic role labellers (SRLs) which, although active areas of research within the general language domain, have received less attention within the bio-IE domain.
Background.relevance: Contextualizes the problem: existing IE systems lack domain-specific annotated corpora for biomedical semantic role labeling, particularly for complex events like gene regulation

Related work.text: Whilst events are often identified by verbs, nominalised verbs play a particularly important role within biomedical texts, and often outnumber other domain-specific verbal forms [25]. However, it is acknowledged that they are more difficult to process than verbs [26] and are currently only dealt with by a small number of systems, often in a limited way (e.g., [17, 27, 28]). [...] Some studies (e.g., [34, 35]) have shown that, to a certain extent, general language resources can also be useful in the training of SRLs for biomedical texts, due to the fact that many verbs appear in texts from both the general language and biomedical domains, and often behave in similar ways. However, the cited works concede that, whilst such SRLs may produce adequate results for certain predicates, training using biomedical corpora is also needed.
Related work.relevance: Highlights the specific gap: nominalized verbs (critical in biomedicine) are under-represented in existing resources, and general-language SRLs are insufficient for domain-specific needs

values.value: Insufficient coverage of sublanguage grammar features in biomedical NLP, including domain-specific syntactic/semantic properties of verbs and nominalizations (e.g., 'methylate', 'translation' as protein synthesis)

Related work.text: NLP systems must take such grammars into account to allow accurate processing of text within specialist domains [37]. Sublanguage grammar features that are relevant to our work include the following: The types of events found in biological sciences are often described using verbs/nominalised verbs that do not feature prominently in general language [26], e.g., methylate. Verbs/nominalised verbs that occur in both the general and specialised language domains may have different syntactic and semantic properties in each domain, e.g., differing numbers of arguments [38], as well as different meanings. For example, translation generally means rendering one language into other, while in Molecular Biology it specifies the process of protein synthesis from an mRNA template.
Related work.relevance: Explicitly identifies the sublanguage grammar gap: domain-specific verbs/nominalizations (e.g., 'methylate', 'translation') have unique syntactic/semantic properties not captured by general-language resources

values.value: Limited interoperability and comparative evaluation of biomedical corpora due to diverse annotation formats and lack of standardized resources for semantic role labeling

Conclusion.text: Firstly, in response to the current diversity of corpus annotation formats and the problems this causes in their comparative evaluation [63], a shared format has been created for resources for biomedical relation extraction [15], together with a standard for the evaluation of relation extraction methods using this data [64]. We plan to convert our own corpus to this format, which has already been carried out for several biomedical corpora, e.g., [13, 16, 21, 23].
Conclusion.relevance: Directly addresses the interoperability problem: diverse annotation formats hinder comparative evaluation and reuse of biomedical corpora

values.value: Poor performance of biomedical IE systems due to lack of richly annotated training data combining linguistic (semantic roles) and biological (concept types) features

Background.text: Semantic searching above the level of concepts depends on prior processing to recognise relations or events in texts, which is carried out by information extraction (IE) systems. [...] Our approach is based on the fact that many events are focussed on either verbs (e.g., transcribe, regulate) or nominalised verbs (e.g., transcription, regulation). Both types of word behave in similar ways, in that they specify arguments that can convey a range of different types of information related to the event. For each relevant event, our annotation aims to identify, as exhaustively as possible, all structurally-related arguments within the same sentence. Each argument is assigned a semantic role from a fixed set of 13 roles. Where appropriate, arguments are also assigned a biological concept type.
Background.relevance: Links IE system performance to the need for combined linguistic (semantic roles) and biological (concept types) annotations

Results.text: Initial machine learning experiments using the GREC [45] suggest that it can be used to train IE components with reasonably good performance, with both named entity extraction and semantic role labelling having achieved F-scores of around 60%, based on 10-fold cross validation.
Results.relevance: Empirical evidence that existing systems suffer from ~60% F-scores, implying room for improvement with richer annotations

values.value: 240 MEDLINE abstracts

Results.text: Using the scheme, we have created the Gene Regulation Event Corpus (GREC), consisting of 240 MEDLINE abstracts, in which events relating to gene regulation and expression have been annotated by biologists.
Results.relevance: Direct mention of the primary material used for constructing the GREC corpus.

Conclusion.text: We have designed an event annotation scheme for biomedical texts and produced an associated corpus, the GREC, consisting of 240 MEDLINE abstracts annotated with 3067 gene regulation event instances.
Conclusion.relevance: Explicit confirmation of the material (240 MEDLINE abstracts) forming the GREC corpus.

Methods.text: Candidate abstracts for annotation for the final GREC were selected from species-specific corpora of MEDLINE abstracts collected by EMBL-EBI, who chose abstracts relevant to the E. coli and human species using their own rule-based species-filtering methods.
Methods.relevance: Describes the source and selection process of the MEDLINE abstracts used as material.

values.value: Gene Regulation Event Corpus (GREC)

Background.text: Our work has been concerned with the development of such a corpus for the biomedical field, the Gene Regulation Event Corpus (GREC), consisting of MEDLINE abstracts semantically annotated with event information.
Background.relevance: Introduces the GREC as the primary material/corpus developed in the study.

Results.text: Using the scheme, we have created the Gene Regulation Event Corpus (GREC), consisting of 240 MEDLINE abstracts, in which events relating to gene regulation and expression have been annotated by biologists.
Results.relevance: Explicitly names the GREC as the output material of the annotation effort.

Conclusion.text: The corpus can act as a basis for creating domain-specific semantic frame resources, and has already been used in the production of semantic frames for inclusion within the BioLexicon [44].
Conclusion.relevance: Reinforces the GREC as a foundational material for further research.

values.value: E. coli and human MEDLINE abstracts

Methods.text: Candidate abstracts for annotation for the final GREC were selected from species-specific corpora of MEDLINE abstracts collected by EMBL-EBI, who chose abstracts relevant to the E. coli and human species using their own rule-based species-filtering methods.
Methods.relevance: Specifies the species-specific focus of the MEDLINE abstracts used as material.

Results.text: Table 5 shows the top 10 most common words (verbs and nominalised verbs) which express events, both in the corpus as a whole, and separately for the E. coli and human parts of the corpus.
Results.relevance: Confirms the division of the corpus material into E. coli and human subsets.

values.value: BioLexicon

Conclusion.text: The corpus has already been used in the development of the BioLexicon [44]. This unique text mining resource for biology provides and links syntactic and semantic frame information for a large number of biomedical sublanguage verbs.
Conclusion.relevance: Identifies BioLexicon as a secondary material/resource derived from or linked to the GREC.

Motivation.text: The GREC consists of 240 MEDLINE abstracts, which have been annotated with a total of 3067 events. Whilst of modest size compared to some other domain-specific event-annotated corpora (e.g., [21]), this is balanced by the richness of the annotations. The corpus has already been used in the development of the BioLexicon [44].
Motivation.relevance: Explicitly connects the GREC material to the BioLexicon resource.

values.value: WordFreak

Methods.text: The annotation of the GREC was performed using a Java-based annotation tool called WordFreak (http://wordfreak.sourceforge.net/[59]).
Methods.relevance: Identifies WordFreak as the software tool used to annotate the GREC material.

values.value: GENIA tagger

Methods.text: Prior to annotation, chunks are automatically identified by the GENIA tagger [55].
Methods.relevance: Explicitly names the GENIA tagger as a tool used in preprocessing the GREC material.

Annotation scheme.text: The basis of this list was a set of 229 hand-picked gene regulation verbs provided by the European Bioinformatics Institute (EMBL-EBI). We augmented this list through the automatic extraction of further verbs from an E. coli corpus. This corpus contains approximately 33,000 MEDLINE abstracts and was also provided by EMBL-EBI. The automatic extraction was carried out by identifying those verbs whose syntactic arguments corresponded either to terms identified by the TerMine tool (http://www.nactem.ac.uk/software/termine/) or biological named entities identified by the GENIA tagger [55].
Annotation scheme.relevance: Confirms the use of the GENIA tagger for named entity recognition in the material.

values.value: TerMine tool

Annotation scheme.text: The automatic extraction was carried out by identifying those verbs whose syntactic arguments corresponded either to terms identified by the TerMine tool (http://www.nactem.ac.uk/software/termine/) or biological named entities identified by the GENIA tagger [55].
Annotation scheme.relevance: Explicitly names the TerMine tool as part of the preprocessing pipeline for the GREC material.

values.value: Gene Regulation Ontology (GRO)

Background.text: Where appropriate, arguments are also assigned a biological concept type linked to the Gene Regulation Ontology.
Background.relevance: Introduces the Gene Regulation Ontology (GRO) as a linked resource for biological concept types in the GREC.

Conclusion.text: From the biological perspective, appropriate arguments are additionally assigned a biological concept type from a hierarchically-structured set that is tailored to the gene regulation domain. The concepts are mapped to classes in the Gene Regulation Ontology (GRO) [43].
Conclusion.relevance: Explicitly connects the GREC material to the Gene Regulation Ontology (GRO).

values.value: UMLS SPECIALIST lexicon

Related work.text: The UMLS SPECIALIST lexicon [41], which includes many biomedical terms, is larger scale, but includes only syntactic, and not semantic, information about verbs.
Related work.relevance: References the UMLS SPECIALIST lexicon as a related resource in the domain, though not directly used in GREC.

values.value: 353 gene regulation verbs

Annotation scheme.text: The basis of this list was a set of 229 hand-picked gene regulation verbs provided by the European Bioinformatics Institute (EMBL-EBI). We augmented this list through the automatic extraction of further verbs from an E. coli corpus. This corpus contains approximately 33,000 MEDLINE abstracts and was also provided by EMBL-EBI. The complete list was subsequently reviewed for relevance by a biology expert, resulting in a list of 353 verbs.
Annotation scheme.relevance: Describes the creation of a list of 353 gene regulation verbs as a supplementary material/resource.

values.value: 33,000 MEDLINE abstracts (E. coli corpus)

Annotation scheme.text: We augmented this list through the automatic extraction of further verbs from an E. coli corpus. This corpus contains approximately 33,000 MEDLINE abstracts and was also provided by EMBL-EBI.
Annotation scheme.relevance: Identifies a secondary corpus of 33,000 MEDLINE abstracts used for verb extraction.

values.value: Annotation scheme centered on verbs and nominalized verbs for gene regulation events, assigning 13 semantic roles and biological concept types linked to the Gene Regulation Ontology (GRO).

Background.text: Our approach is based on the fact that many events are focussed on either verbs (e.g., transcribe, regulate) or nominalised verbs (e.g., transcription, regulation). Both types of word behave in similar ways, in that they specify arguments that can convey a range of different types of information related to the event. For each relevant event, our annotation aims to identify, as exhaustively as possible, all structurally-related arguments within the same sentence. Each argument is assigned a semantic role from a fixed set of 13 roles. Where appropriate, arguments are also assigned a biological concept type. The GREC may be downloaded from http://www.nactem.ac.uk/GREC/.
Background.relevance: Describes the core methodology of semantic role labeling (SRL) and biological concept assignment for gene regulation events, explicitly mentioning the use of verbs/nominalized verbs and the 13-role scheme.

Results.text: We have defined a new scheme for annotating sentence-bound gene regulation events, centred on both verbs and nominalised verbs. For each event instance, all participants (arguments) in the same sentence are identified and assigned a semantic role from a rich set of 13 roles tailored to biomedical research articles, together with a biological concept type linked to the Gene Regulation Ontology.
Results.relevance: Directly states the methodological focus on verbs/nominalized verbs, 13 semantic roles, and GRO-linked biological concepts.

values.value: Iterative annotator training with quantitative inter-annotator agreement (IAA) scoring using F-measure, including 5 fortnightly cycles with feedback and group discussions to refine guidelines.

Methods.text: Initial training sessions introduced the annotation tool and the task, with a particular emphasis being placed on clear positive and negative examples of gene regulation and expression events. This was considered particularly important for those annotators with less experience in gene regulation and expression. The initial training sessions were followed up by 5 fortnightly cycles, during which abstracts were firstly annotated by the annotators and then examined by 2 of the authors (one with biological expertise and the other with linguistic expertise), who produced individual feedback reports for each annotator prior to the start of the next cycle of annotation. Additional regular group sessions allowed problems to be discussed in more detail. The calculation of IAA scores after each training cycle provided a quantitative measure of improvement during the training period.
Methods.relevance: Details the structured training methodology, including iterative cycles, feedback, and IAA scoring to ensure annotation consistency.

Calculating inter-annotator agreement.text: We have defined a novel evaluation methodology which calculates IAA for a number of separate subtasks of the annotation process. [...] Whilst the Kappa statistic has become a standard way of calculating IAA for classification tasks, it is problematic for most of the annotation subtasks outlined above, as it requires classifications to correspond to mutually exclusive and discrete categories. [...] We have thus chosen to follow [61] in choosing the F-Score to calculate IAA, as it can be applied straightforwardly to all of the above annotation subtasks.
Calculating inter-annotator agreement.relevance: Explains the use of F-measure (instead of Kappa) for quantifying IAA across multiple annotation subtasks, which is a key part of the training method.

values.value: Automated chunk-based span annotation using GENIA tagger to ensure consistent argument text spans, excluding descriptive prepositional phrases (e.g., 'of 23 kDa').

Consistent annotation of text spans.text: In order to promote consistent choice of spans, we have created a number of guidelines which are mostly based on syntactic chunks. Prior to annotation, chunks are automatically identified by the GENIA tagger. [...] According to our guidelines, annotated text spans should normally consist of (sequences of) complete chunks, thus alleviating many issues relating to the exact words that should be included within an argument text span. [...] A further guideline stipulates that argument text spans must consist only of base NP chunks, and that additional descriptive information, usually introduced by prepositions, must be excluded from argument text spans.
Consistent annotation of text spans.relevance: Describes the method for ensuring consistent argument span annotation via GENIA tagger chunks and explicit exclusion of descriptive prepositional phrases.

values.value: Customized WordFreak annotation tool with automated verb highlighting, chunk color-coding, and role-specific chunk restrictions (e.g., ADVP chunks limited to MANNER role).

Software.text: The annotation of the GREC was performed using a Java-based annotation tool called WordFreak. [...] The customisation helps annotators to conform to the guidelines in a number of ways. For example, occurrences of biologically-relevant verbs are automatically highlighted. In addition, colour-coding is used to distinguish different types of chunks, whilst certain restrictions are imposed in the tool as regards the types of chunks that can constitute different types of semantic arguments, e.g., ADVP chunks can only be labelled with the MANNER role.
Software.relevance: Describes the tool customization (WordFreak) to enforce guidelines via verb highlighting, chunk color-coding, and role-chunk restrictions.

values.value: Corpus selection via EMBL-EBI species-filtered MEDLINE abstracts (E. coli and human), further screened for gene regulation relevance by a biology expert.

Corpus characteristics and statistics.text: Candidate abstracts for annotation for the final GREC were selected from species-specific corpora of MEDLINE abstracts collected by EMBL-EBI, who chose abstracts relevant to the E. coli and human species using their own rule-based species-filtering methods. The candidate abstracts were further screened for relevance to gene regulation by one of the authors with biological expertise.
Corpus characteristics and statistics.relevance: Explains the two-step corpus selection method: EMBL-EBI species filtering followed by expert screening for gene regulation relevance.

values.value: Multi-faceted inter-annotator agreement (IAA) evaluation using F-score for 5 subtasks: event identification, argument identification (relaxed/exact spans), semantic role assignment, biological concept identification, and category assignment (exact/parent/supercategory).

Calculating inter-annotator agreement.text: We have defined a novel evaluation methodology which calculates IAA for a number of separate subtasks of the annotation process. These subtasks are as follows: Event identification (how frequently annotators agree on which events to annotate); Argument identification (for agreed events, how frequently the same arguments are chosen by each annotator). For this task, we calculate separate agreement rates corresponding to: a. Relaxed span matches, where argument text spans identified by a pair of annotators at least overlap with each other, but do not necessarily match exactly. b. Exact span matches, where argument text spans identified by a pair of annotators match exactly.; Semantic role assignment (for agreed arguments, how often the same semantic roles are assigned by each annotator); Biological concept identification (within agreed arguments, how often annotators identify the same biological concepts); Biological concept category assignment (for agreed biological concepts, how often the assigned categories are agreed upon by each annotator). For this task, we calculate 3 different agreement rates, i.e., a. Exact category matches, where each annotator has assigned exactly the same concept label. b. Matches including parent, where we also consider as matches those cases where the category assigned by one annotator is the parent concept of the category assigned by the other annotator. c. Supercategory assignment, where we consider only whether each annotator has assigned a concept within the same top level superclass, i.e., Nucleic_Acids, Proteins, Living_Systems, Processes and Experimental.
Calculating inter-annotator agreement.relevance: Comprehensively lists all 6 IAA subtasks and their evaluation criteria, including relaxed/exact spans and hierarchical concept matching (parent/supercategory).

values.value: Hierarchical biological concept assignment using the Gene Regulation Ontology (GRO), with annotators instructed to assign the most specific concept possible (66.91% achieved).

Biological concepts.text: Annotators were instructed to assign the most specific concept possible in the hierarchy; the results show that 66.91% of assignments indeed constitute the most specific concepts.
Biological concepts.relevance: Describes the method of hierarchical concept assignment tied to GRO, with a quantitative result (66.91%) for specificity compliance.

values.value: Post-training quality control via double-annotation of 25% of abstracts by all annotators, with manual discrepancy analysis to refine guidelines.

Quality control.text: To ensure annotation quality was maintained in the final GREC, approximately one quarter of the abstracts was annotated by all annotators. [...] Finally, we examine some types of annotator discrepancies that were found through manual examination of the corpus.
Quality control.relevance: Describes the quality control method: double-annotation of 25% of abstracts and manual discrepancy analysis.

values.value: Domain-specific semantic role set (13 roles) derived from VerbNet/PropBank but tailored for biomedicine, including CONDITION and DESCRIPTIVE-THEME/AGENT roles for gene regulation events.

Semantic roles.text: Starting with the generic semantic roles proposed for VerbNet [29] and PropBank [30], we examined a large number of relevant events within MEDLINE abstracts, in consultation with biologists. We concluded that arguments of gene regulation and expression events may be characterised using a subset of these general language roles, with the addition of the domain-specific CONDITION role. [...] The full set of roles is shown in Table 2. In general, definitions of argument types normally specified as adjuncts, such as MANNER, INSTRUMENT, CONDITION and LOCATION, can be problematic to distinguish from each other. However, our use of more biologically-oriented definitions for these cases aims to reduce discrepancies.
Semantic roles.relevance: Explains the adaptation of VerbNet/PropBank roles for biomedicine, including the addition of CONDITION and DESCRIPTIVE-THEME/AGENT, with biological definitions to reduce ambiguity.

values.value: Verb/nominalized verb list compilation via EMBL-EBI hand-picked verbs (229) augmented by automatic extraction from an E. coli corpus (33k abstracts) using TerMine and GENIA tagger, reviewed by a biology expert (final list: 353 verbs).

Gene regulation and expression events.text: Annotators were helped by (but not restricted to) a list of verbs which we created that potentially denote gene regulation and expression events. These are automatically highlighted by the annotation software, WordFreak, in each abstract to be annotated. The basis of this list was a set of 229 hand-picked gene regulation verbs provided by the European Bioinformatics Institute (EMBL-EBI). We augmented this list through the automatic extraction of further verbs from an E. coli corpus. This corpus contains approximately 33,000 MEDLINE abstracts and was also provided by EMBL-EBI. The automatic extraction was carried out by identifying those verbs whose syntactic arguments corresponded either to terms identified by the TerMine tool or biological named entities identified by the GENIA tagger. The complete list was subsequently reviewed for relevance by a biology expert, resulting in a list of 353 verbs.
Gene regulation and expression events.relevance: Details the method for compiling the verb list: EMBL-EBI hand-picked verbs (229) + automatic extraction from 33k E. coli abstracts using TerMine/GENIA, reviewed by an expert (final: 353 verbs).

values.value: The Gene Regulation Event Corpus (GREC) was created, consisting of 240 MEDLINE abstracts annotated with 3067 gene regulation event instances, featuring a rich set of 13 semantic roles tailored to biomedical research and linked to the Gene Regulation Ontology (GRO).

Results.text: We have defined a new scheme for annotating sentence-bound gene regulation events, centred on both verbs and nominalised verbs. For each event instance, all participants (arguments) in the same sentence are identified and assigned a semantic role from a rich set of 13 roles tailored to biomedical research articles, together with a biological concept type linked to the Gene Regulation Ontology. To our knowledge, our scheme is unique within the biomedical field in terms of the range of event arguments identified. Using the scheme, we have created the Gene Regulation Event Corpus (GREC), consisting of 240 MEDLINE abstracts, in which events relating to gene regulation and expression have been annotated by biologists. A novel method of evaluating various different facets of the annotation task showed that average inter-annotator agreement rates fall within the range of 66% - 90%.
Results.relevance: Directly describes the creation of GREC, its size (240 abstracts, 3067 events), and its unique features (13 semantic roles, linkage to GRO).

values.value: Average inter-annotator agreement rates for GREC annotation tasks ranged from 66% to 90% F-score, with semantic role assignment and argument identification achieving 88% or higher agreement.

Results.text: A novel method of evaluating various different facets of the annotation task showed that average inter-annotator agreement rates fall within the range of 66% - 90%.
Results.relevance: Provides quantitative validation of GREC's annotation quality via inter-annotator agreement metrics.

Conclusion.text: Average agreement rates for the various tasks fell within the range of 66% - 90% F-score. Through error analysis of the corpus, we identified the most problematic issues, which included difficulties in assigning particular semantic roles, particularly CONDITION and DESCRIPTIVE-THEME. [...] Particularly high levels of agreement (88% or above) are achieved for both the identification of semantic arguments and the assignment of semantic roles to these arguments.
Conclusion.relevance: Reinforces the F-score range and highlights specific high-agreement tasks (semantic roles, argument identification).

values.value: GREC combines linguistically-oriented features (event-independent semantic roles tuned to biomedicine) and biologically-oriented features (biological concepts linked to the Gene Regulation Ontology), enabling flexible queries like 'LOCATION:E. coli, AGENT:NifA activates which THEME:GENE'.

Conclusion.text: The corpus is unique within the biomedical field in that it combines both linguistically-oriented features (i.e., event-independent semantic roles tuned to the domain) and biologically-oriented features (i.e., biological concepts linked to the Gene Regulation Ontology [43]). [...] The combination of semantic role and biological concept labels provides a rich annotation, aimed at allowing users to have a large amount of flexibility over the type of query they specify and to have control over the specificity or generality of certain parts of the query, e.g.: In LOCATION:E. coli, AGENT:NifA activates which THEME:GENE.
Conclusion.relevance: Explains GREC's dual linguistic/biological design and its practical utility for flexible queries.

values.value: Initial machine learning experiments using GREC achieved F-scores of ~60% for both named entity extraction and semantic role labelling (10-fold cross-validation), demonstrating its utility for training biomedical IE systems.

Motivation.text: Initial machine learning experiments using the GREC [45] suggest that it can be used to train IE components with reasonably good performance, with both named entity extraction and semantic role labelling having achieved F-scores of around 60%, based on 10-fold cross validation.
Motivation.relevance: Provides empirical validation of GREC's applicability to machine learning tasks in biomedical IE.

values.value: GREC's semantic role set (13 roles) was found sufficient to characterize 3067 events, with the 'Underspecified' role used only 11 times, indicating comprehensive coverage of gene regulation/expression arguments.

Results and discussion.text: In addition to the 13 roles already introduced, there is a further role named Underspecified, which was to be assigned by annotators to arguments that could not be characterised by one of the 13 defined roles. However, the fact that the Underspecified role was only assigned 11 times in the whole corpus suggests that our originally-defined role set is sufficient to characterise the vast majority of semantic arguments.
Results and discussion.relevance: Validates the adequacy of the 13-role scheme for annotating 3067 events, with minimal use of the 'Underspecified' fallback.

values.value: GREC's biological concept assignments achieved high agreement for coarse-grained categories but faced challenges with fine-grained classification, particularly for 'Gene' (dominant but rarely subtyped) and 'Transcription_Factor' (more frequent in human than E. coli abstracts).

Conclusion.text: As regards biological concepts, our results show that, although high levels of agreement can be achieved when considering a coarse-grained set of categories, the use of a fine-grained classification caused some difficulties. [...] Gene constitutes the most commonly assigned concept in both parts of the corpus. It is a general, rather than a specific concept in the Nucleic_Acids hierarchy. However, the frequency of assignments of its specific subtypes, i.e., Mutant_Gene, ORF and Allele is very low, with 19, 10 and 1 assignments, respectively. [...] The category Transcription_Factor also has far more assignments than its sub-categories, Repressor and Activator in the human part of the corpus. However, Transcription_Factor is not nearly as frequent in E. coli abstracts as in human corpus.
Conclusion.relevance: Highlights the coarse vs. fine-grained agreement disparity and species-specific concept distribution (e.g., Transcription_Factor in human vs. E. coli).

values.value: Error analysis revealed that the most problematic semantic roles for annotators were CONDITION (often confused with MANNER/TEMPORAL) and DESCRIPTIVE-THEME (confused with THEME), suggesting a need for refined role definitions or additional training.

Quality control.text: Amongst the most important semantic roles, both in terms of frequency of occurrence and according to [20], CONDITION is the one with the lowest rates of agreement. [...] The most common confusions are with the MANNER and TEMPORAL roles. [...] Regarding the DESCRIPTIVE-THEME role, the most common type of confusion is with THEME. [...] In general, DESCRIPTIVE-THEME and DESCRIPTIVE-AGENT have less strict definitions than other roles, in that the only restriction imposed is that they should be assigned to arguments that describe characteristics or behaviour of the AGENT or THEME. This, together with the fact that they are not particularly commonly occurring, could have made them more difficult to assign accurately.
Quality control.relevance: Identifies specific roles (CONDITION, DESCRIPTIVE-THEME) as sources of annotator confusion and proposes solutions (refined definitions, training).

values.value: GREC's annotation scheme was applied to 240 MEDLINE abstracts (120 E. coli, 120 human) by 6 biology PhD annotators over 876 person-hours, with training emphasizing syntactic chunk-based span consistency and domain-specific semantic role definitions.

Methods.text: Candidate abstracts for annotation for the final GREC were selected from species-specific corpora of MEDLINE abstracts collected by EMBL-EBI, who chose abstracts relevant to the E. coli and human species using their own rule-based species-filtering methods. The candidate abstracts were further screened for relevance to gene regulation by one of the authors with biological expertise. [...] The effort expended by the 6 annotators amounted to a total of 876 person hours (equivalent to 6.4 person months).
Methods.relevance: Details the corpus composition (240 abstracts, split by species), annotator profile (6 biology PhDs), and effort (876 hours).

Annotation scheme.text: To accompany the annotation scheme, we have produced a detailed set of annotation guidelines, as these are necessary to aid in the achievement of high quality annotations [5254]. The structure and content of these guidelines were iteratively refined in discussion with domain experts and with annotators (via group discussion sessions following annotation training phrases and full annotation cycles).
Annotation scheme.relevance: Highlights the iterative guideline refinement and emphasis on syntactic chunks/span consistency.

values.value: GREC's top 10 event-triggering verbs/nominalizations (e.g., 'regulate/regulation', 'bind/binding', 'express/expression') account for 4550% of all annotated events, with nominalized verbs (e.g., 'expression') dominating in E. coli abstracts.

Results and discussion.text: Table 5 shows the top 10 most common words (verbs and nominalised verbs) which express events, both in the corpus as a whole, and separately for the E. coli and human parts of the corpus. In each case, events centred on these 10 words constitute 45 - 50% of the total events annotated, suggesting that the majority of relevant events are centred on a relatively small set of words. [...] In the E. coli portion of the corpus, for example, twice as many events are centred on the nominalised verb expression than any other word.
Results and discussion.relevance: Quantifies the dominance of top 10 verbs/nominalizations (4550% of events) and highlights species-specific patterns (e.g., 'expression' in E. coli).

old_values.value: Future work includes converting GREC to a shared biomedical relation extraction format and integrating it into the U-Compare system to enhance interoperability and accessibility for text mining tasks.

Conclusion.text: Firstly, in response to the current diversity of corpus annotation formats and the problems this causes in their comparative evaluation [63], a shared format has been created for resources for biomedical relation extraction [15], together with a standard for the evaluation of relation extraction methods using this data [64]. We plan to convert our own corpus to this format, which has already been carried out for several biomedical corpora, e.g., [13, 16, 21, 23]. Secondly, we plan to develop a corpus reader which will allow the GREC to be made available within the U-Compare system [65](http://u-compare.org).
Conclusion.relevance: Outlines concrete plans for GREC's format conversion and integration into U-Compare for broader usability.

metadata.title: Construction of an annotated corpus to support biomedical information extraction
metadata.abstract: AbstractBackgroundInformation Extraction (IE) is a component of text mining that facilitates knowledge discovery by automatically locating instances of interesting biomedical events from huge document collections. As events are usually centred on verbs and nominalised verbs, understanding the syntactic and semantic behaviour of these words is highly important. Corpora annotated with information concerning this behaviour can constitute a valuable resource in the training of IE components and resources.ResultsWe have defined a new scheme for annotating sentence-bound gene regulation events, centred on both verbs and nominalised verbs. For each event instance, all participants (arguments) in the same sentence are identified and assigned a semantic role from a rich set of 13 roles tailored to biomedical research articles, together with a biological concept type linked to the Gene Regulation Ontology. To our knowledge, our scheme is unique within the biomedical field in terms of the range of event arguments identified. Using the scheme, we have created the Gene Regulation Event Corpus (GREC), consisting of 240 MEDLINE abstracts, in which events relating to gene regulation and expression have been annotated by biologists. A novel method of evaluating various different facets of the annotation task showed that average inter-annotator agreement rates fall within the range of 66% - 90%.ConclusionThe GREC is a unique resource within the biomedical field, in that it annotates not only core relationships between entities, but also a range of other important details about these relationships, e.g., location, temporal, manner and environmental conditions. As such, it is specifically designed to support bio-specific tool and resource development. It has already been used to acquire semantic frames for inclusion within theBioLexicon(a lexical, terminological resource to aid biomedical text mining). Initial experiments have also shown that the corpus may viably be used to train IE components, such as semantic role labellers. The corpus and annotation guidelines are freely available for academic purposes.

values.value: Lack of domain-specific linguistically-oriented corpora for semantic frame information and semantic role labeling in biomedical information extraction, particularly for gene regulation and expression events

Motivation.text: Existing event corpora within the domain (e.g., [21] and [23]) are not specifically geared to support the acquisition of semantic frame information for verbs. The bio-NLP community has, until now, lacked a domain-specific linguistically-oriented corpus in which detailed semantic information for a wide range of both verbs and nominalised verbs has been annotated. This has limited the amount of research undertaken on the production of domain-specific semantic frame resources and SRLs.
Motivation.relevance: Directly states the core research problem addressed by the GREC corpus: absence of domain-specific annotated resources for semantic frame extraction in biomedical texts, particularly for gene regulation/expression events

Background.text: Due to domain-specific features of texts and the types of events to be recognised, IE systems must be adapted to deal with specific domains. A well-established method of carrying out this adaptation is through training using annotated corpora (e.g., [1012]). [...] our annotation aims to identify, as exhaustively as possible, all structurally-related arguments within the same sentence. [...] To our knowledge, the GREC provides the richest annotation to date within the biomedical field, in terms of the number of arguments types and their characterisation. As such, the corpus is specifically designed to contribute to the development of bio-specific semantic frame resources and semantic role labellers (SRLs) which, although active areas of research within the general language domain, have received less attention within the bio-IE domain.
Background.relevance: Contextualizes the problem: existing IE systems lack domain-specific annotated corpora for biomedical semantic role labeling, particularly for complex events like gene regulation

Related work.text: Whilst events are often identified by verbs, nominalised verbs play a particularly important role within biomedical texts, and often outnumber other domain-specific verbal forms [25]. However, it is acknowledged that they are more difficult to process than verbs [26] and are currently only dealt with by a small number of systems, often in a limited way (e.g., [17, 27, 28]). [...] Some studies (e.g., [34, 35]) have shown that, to a certain extent, general language resources can also be useful in the training of SRLs for biomedical texts, due to the fact that many verbs appear in texts from both the general language and biomedical domains, and often behave in similar ways.
